doc.after: The earliest works of Japanese literature include the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki chronicles and the Man'yÅshÅ« poetry anthology, all from the 8th century and written in Chinese characters.[203][204] In the early Heian period, the system of phonograms known as kana (Hiragana and Katakana) was developed. The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter is considered the oldest Japanese narrative.[205] An account of Heian court life is given in The Pillow Book by Sei ShÅnagon, while The Tale of Genji by Murasaki Shikibu is often described as the world's first novel.[206][207]
